They average between 45 mins to an hour long and devote three episodes to the Italian Neorealism movement and not sure how many episodes there are for the French new wave but the time dedicated to it is decent. Can’t really complain about what you’re getting for free, especially from MIT, I guess.

This video is yet another tiresome and highly inaccurate portrayal of the American Independent film movement. The movement is the result of early works by the likes of John Cassavetes, Morris Engel and Ruth Orkin. Following in their tradition is the late Barbara Loden, Jim Jarmusch, late Robert Altman, Kelly Reichhart, Andrew Bujalski, Todd Haynes, late Charles Burrnet  and many others. Please spend more time researching before attempting to summarize crucial film history.

Strong misconception in this video that repeats the myth that Spielberg and Lucas have nothing to do with "New Hollywood" and just "invented" the Blockbuster. The truth is that Lucas and especially Spielberg where very much part of the New Hollywood movement  and even formed a tight group with the likes of Coppola, De Palma and Scorsese. This group even had a nickname: The Movie Brats.

This was a great addition to a great series, but how can you talk about the fifties and NOT mention the Hollywood Blacklist and the House Un-American Activities Committee? Conformity was the dominate theme throughout the post-war period in the US and suppressed the creative spirits of several aspiring filmmakers. The Cold War was a huge part of our history; the struggle on screen between capitalism and communism would have been so interesting for Crash Course to explore.

As much as I like this episode I feel it's from a very american prospective. "Film History" and "American Film History" are two very distinctive things. I don't think it makes any sense to talk about "independant cinema" when you are mentioning the neo realismo or la Nouvelle vague française. These are just movements that happened in other film industries around the world (in France, especially, the market was really far from being dominated by american movies) and that also happened to shape to way filmmakers would make movies in Hollywood. Independant cinema would be the Tarantino & consorts and the Linklaters of today.

Good episode, although I don't entirely agree with the statement about blockbusters being removed from political stances. In my opinion, the best blockbusters are the ones that weave political allegories into their storylines (albeit not overtly). To take just two examples: several elements of Star Wars are pretty clearly influenced by the fact that the first movie had its genesis during the Watergate crisis, and the storyline of Captain America: The Winter Soldier has a number of thematic parallels to the US government's reaction to the terrorist attacks on September 11, 2001. Of course, these blockbusters can also be fun entertainment, but to claim that they merely represent a form of escape is to downplay their impact on society.

New Hollywood cinema was a great era for grittier films with generally an "R" rating like Taxi Driver, The Deer Hunter, 2001: A Space Odyssey, The Shining, and The Godfather. I thought Star Wars was a terrible movie, and just plain dumb when I saw it in the theater as a kid. Movies of this ilk tended to be sanitized, dumbed down, and PG rated. People would constantly babble way too much about "special effects" from that point on.

I enjoy learning all this new information, but I would like to point out one thing: One woman. That's it. I'm sure there are others out there and I hope that a future episode will be dedicated to women directors. Yet how much material is out there about women directors in these art movements? A Google search only brings up the names of male directors even when female is specified. There are several lists of contemporary women directors who have done indie films and that is heartening. Yet once again I am struck at how only one woman, Agnes Varda, is mentioned here. Where are the others? They had to have been there. But where are they? It speaks so deeply to how much women have been erased from history when only one is able to be mentioned here. I'd like to state that I am not criticizing what has been presented here, this is a criticism of our world patriarchal culture that has worked to keep women out and erase or minimize those who "got in." Please keep up the great work Crash Course, I'm looking forward to learning more with you soon.
